study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of methyl jasmonate (MeJA)-induced senescence on chlorophyll biosynthesis and protective mechanisms in rice plants.
results_summary: MeJA treatment led to oxidative stress, decreased chlorophyll content, and reduced photosynthetic efficiency in rice plants. Protective mechanisms, including enzymatic antioxidant responses and degradation of chlorophyll precursors, were activated to mitigate oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Rice plants (Oryza sativa)
study_duration: Observations made up to 78 hours after MeJA treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how OsRACK1B regulates chlorophyll metabolism and delays salinity-induced senescence in rice plants.
results_summary: The study found that overexpression of OsRACK1B negatively regulates chlorophyll degradation, stabilizes LHC-II isoform Lhcb1, and delays salinity-induced senescence, while down-regulation accelerates yellowing. Transcript and protein profiling revealed altered expression of senescence-associated genes, suggesting a novel regulatory mechanism involving OsRACK1B-OsSGR-TFs.
population_specificity: Transgenic rice (Oryza sativa L.) plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how exogenous calcium levels affect chlorophyll fluorescence properties, growth, and antioxidant systems in Fraxinus malacophylla seedlings.
results_summary: Exogenous calcium (25-50 mmol L-1) promoted growth, biomass accumulation, root activity, chlorophyll synthesis, and enhanced PSII function in Fraxinus malacophylla seedlings. Antioxidant enzyme activities (POD and CAT) were upregulated, reducing oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Fraxinus malacophylla seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ALA and ABA improve iron utilization and chlorophyll synthesis in tomato seedlings under low-temperature stress and elucidate their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Exogenous ALA increased chlorophyll accumulation by 15.18%, improved iron utilization, and enhanced photochemical efficiency under low-temperature stress. ABA showed similar effects, suggesting crosstalk between ABA and ALA in regulating chlorophyll synthesis and stress resistance.
population_specificity: Tomato seedlings under low-temperature stress (8-18°C/8-12°C day/night).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a combined system (Hydrodynamic Cavitation, Ozone, and Hydrogen Peroxide) in removing Chlorophyll a and organic substances from raw water.
results_summary: The study found that the combined system achieved maximum reduction in Chlorophyll a and Total Organic Carbon under optimized conditions (pH 5, cavitation pressure 5 bar, flow rate 1 m³/h, etc.), with cavitation pressure being the most influential factor. Hydrogen Peroxide had the least impact on degradation efficiency.
population_specificity: Raw water samples (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: O3 3 g/h and H2O2 2 g/l concentrations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of various metal and metal(oid) oxide nanoparticles on the photosynthetic performance of oakleaf lettuce seedlings, using chlorophyll a fluorescence and leaf reflectance measurements.
results_summary: The study found that nanoparticles influenced chlorophyll a fluorescence parameters and leaf reflectance, with Fe2O3 and TiO2 nanoparticles causing the most significant changes. While some nanoparticles initially caused minor leaf damage, plants fully recovered by the 9th day.
population_specificity: Oakleaf lettuce seedlings
effective_dosage: Suspensions of NPs with concentrations: 6% TiO2, SiO2; 3% CeO2, SnO2, Fe2O3; 0.004% (40 ppm) Ag; 0.002% (20 ppm) Au

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) additions on photosynthesis and chlorophyll fluorescence (ChlF) in Cyclocarya paliurus seedlings.
results_summary: N and P additions significantly altered photosynthesis and ChlF, with optimal performance observed at 150.0 mg(N) L-1 and 25.0 mg(P) L-1 for net photosynthetic rate (P N) and PSII efficiency (ФPSII), and at 150.0 mg(N) L-1 and 15.0 mg(P) L-1 for maximum quantum yield (Fv/Fm) and water-use efficiency (WUE). Positive correlations were found between P N and chlorophyll content, transpiration rate, WUE, Fv/Fm, and ΦPSII.
population_specificity: Cyclocarya paliurus seedlings
effective_dosage: 150.0 mg(N) L-1 and 25.0 mg(P) L-1 (optimal for P N and ФPSII); 150.0 mg(N) L-1 and 15.0 mg(P) L-1 (optimal for Fv/Fm and WUE)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of auxin in regulating chlorophyll biosynthesis and its impact on photosynthetic efficiency in plants.
results_summary: The study found that auxin negatively regulates chlorophyll biosynthesis by suppressing key genes (PORA and GUN5), leading to higher chlorophyll content and improved photosynthetic efficiency in auxin-defective mutants.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (plant model organism)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of BnMYB69 genes in plant development, including their impact on chlorophyll content and related metabolic pathways.
results_summary: The study found that BnMYB69 RNA interference led to increased leaf chlorophyll content, alongside changes in other metabolic pathways such as reduced shikimates and proanthocyanidin levels.
population_specificity: Brassica napus (oilseed rape) plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether seed inoculation with Bacillus pumilus could protect wheat plants from combined salt and arsenic stress by improving growth, water status, and photosynthetic efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that B. pumilus inoculation alleviated stress-induced declines in growth, water content, and chlorophyll fluorescence in wheat plants, while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity and reducing oxidative damage under combined salt and arsenic stress.
population_specificity: Wheat plants (Triticum aestivum) at the vegetative stage.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Chlorophyll; stress conditions were 100 mM NaCl and 200 μM sodium arsenate.
study_duration: 72 hours of stress exposure after three weeks of growth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preharvest application of nitric oxide (via sodium nitroprusside) could delay leaf yellowing and senescence in Chinese flowering cabbage by modulating chlorophyll metabolism and antioxidant pathways.
results_summary: Preharvest SNP treatment reduced leaf yellowing, enhanced chlorophyll biosynthesis, suppressed chlorophyll degradation, increased flavonoid synthesis, and delayed senescence by reducing reactive oxygen species accumulation. Proteomic analysis identified 198 differentially expressed proteins linked to chlorophyll metabolism and antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Chinese flowering cabbage (Brassica campestris L. ssp. chinensis var. utilis Tsen et Lee)
effective_dosage: 50 mg L-1 sodium nitroprusside (SNP) applied to roots

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetic profile and anti-cancer activity of fluorinated and iodinated photosensitizers derived from chlorophyll analogs.
results_summary: The study found that fluorinated and iodinated photosensitizers showed similar fluorescence and singlet oxygen production, but differed in tumor uptake timing. The m-fluoro photosensitizer demonstrated the best anti-cancer activity in mice with brain or bladder tumors, with higher tumor uptake correlating with better PDT efficacy.
population_specificity: Mice bearing U87 (brain) or UMUC3 (bladder) tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how drought tolerance affects chlorophyll fluorescence parameters (Fv/Fm, yield, NPQ) in two Mediterranean tree species (Quercus ilex and Phillyrea latifolia) under long-term precipitation exclusion.
results_summary: The study found that Fv/Fm and NPQ levels correlated positively with temperature and SPEI, while yield was higher under drought treatment and negatively associated with vapor pressure deficit and SPEI. Q. ilex showed higher yield and lower NPQ than P. latifolia, suggesting better acclimation to drought conditions.
population_specificity: Mediterranean forest trees (Quercus ilex and Phillyrea latifolia)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of controlled copper addition on maintaining the green color of Castelvetrano-style table olives by analyzing chlorophyll derivatives during storage and packaging.
results_summary: The study found that copper in storage or packaging brines significantly maintained the green color of olives, associated with a specific pattern of chlorophyll derivatives. Re-greening was achievable even for olives that had yellowed after 18 months, and a short-term thermic treatment was identified as a predictive tool for chlorophyll derivative stability.
population_specificity: Nocellara cultivar table olives debittered industrially using the Castelvetrano method.
effective_dosage: Copper concentration below the EU legislative limit (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: 3 months in alkaline brines, followed by up to 18 months in acid brines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of injectable chlorophyll (30 and 60 mg/ml) on enhancing blood parameters in rats.
results_summary: Treatment with liquid chlorophyll significantly increased multiple hematological parameters (WBCs, RBCs, granulocytes, lymphocytes, Hgb, Hct, MCHC, and platelets) but nonsignificantly increased MCV. The platelet count showed a particularly strong increase (p<0.001) at both concentrations.
population_specificity: Twenty-one white male rats divided into control, 30 mg/ml, and 60 mg/ml groups.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/ml and 60 mg/ml, administered via injection.
study_duration: Effects were measured at 14 and 28 days post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of melatonin pretreatment on chlorophyll synthesis and fluorescence parameters in Malva parviflora exposed to cadmium.
results_summary: Melatonin increased chlorophyll content and precursors of chlorophyll biosynthesis while reducing degradation, improving photochemical efficiency of PSII under cadmium stress.
population_specificity: 42-day-old Malva parviflora plants
study_duration: 10 days (2 days pretreatment + 8 days cadmium exposure)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cold treatment affects chlorophyll degradation in postharvest bananas under high-temperature storage and identify the molecular mechanisms involved.
results_summary: Cold treatment accelerated chlorophyll degradation in bananas by upregulating MaCBR and MaSGR1 expression, mediated by MaCBF1 activation. Transient expression of MaCBF1 further enhanced chlorophyll degradation and mitigated high-temperature-induced green ripening.
population_specificity: Postharvest banana fruit

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop Chlorella mutants with reduced chlorophyll content for improved protein production via fermentation.
results_summary: The study successfully isolated a mutant (P. ks 4) with a 98.78% reduction in chlorophyll a, undetectable chlorophyll b, and high protein content (39.25% dry weight) and productivity (1.15 g/(L·d)). The mutant also produced lutein, giving the biomass a golden-yellow appearance.
population_specificity: Chlorella microalgae cells (mixotrophic wild type and mutants).
effective_dosage: Basal medium containing 30 g/L glucose and 5 g/L NaNO3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the response mechanism of Elymus nutans Griseb. to cadmium (Cd) stress, including its effects on chlorophyll content.
results_summary: The study found that chlorophyll A, chlorophyll B, and chlorophyll AB accumulation decreased with increasing Cd stress concentration, indicating Cd negatively impacts chlorophyll production. Carotenoid content remained largely unaffected by Cd treatment.
population_specificity: Elymus nutans Griseb., a native alpine plant of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a chlorophyll fluorescence imaging (CFI) system to measure the photosynthetic efficiency (Fv/Fm) of strawberry plants under different abiotic stress conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the developed CFI system accurately captured spatial and temporal dynamics of strawberry plants' photosynthetic responses to stress, showing strong correlation (r = 0.75) with a chlorophyll meter. The system detected significant differences in Fv/Fm values among control and stress-treated groups.
population_specificity: Strawberry plants (120 pots divided into four treatment groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on measurement methodology, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a synergistic anti-tumor therapeutic modality combining CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing and photodynamic therapy using Chlorophyll (Chl) as a photosensitizer.
results_summary: Chlorophyll encapsulated in Pluronic F127 micelles effectively generated reactive oxygen species (ROS) under laser irradiation to kill tumor cells, while CRISPR/Cas9 targeting APE1 and NRF2 genes reprogrammed the tumor microenvironment, significantly inhibiting tumor growth in a murine model.
population_specificity: Murine tumor model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the physiological basis behind the negative impacts of warming on the chlorophyll a fluorescence and photosynthetic performance of the lichen Psora decipiens, a key biocrust constituent in drylands.
results_summary: Simulated warming and associated moisture reduction negatively impacted the physiology of Psora decipiens, particularly during spring diurnal periods, by reducing net photosynthesis periods and declining photosynthetic yield (Yield and Fv/Fm). These effects could limit lichen growth and cover, impacting soil attributes like biogeochemical cycles and erosion control.
population_specificity: Biocrust-forming lichen Psora decipiens in drylands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how postharvest treatment with 6-BA at various concentrations affects the quality, chlorophyll content, and senescence of Chinese flowering cabbage during storage.
results_summary: 6-BA treatments (especially 20 and 40 mg·L-1) reduced leaf yellowing, maintained chlorophyll a and b levels, enhanced antioxidant capacity, and delayed senescence by modulating gene expression related to chlorophyll degradation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Harvested Chinese flowering cabbage (Brassica rapa var. parachinensis).
study_duration: Duration of storage not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of atmospheric cold plasma (ACP) treatments on chlorophyll metabolism, sensory quality, and physiological changes in postharvest tomatoes.
results_summary: The 60 kV ACP treatment inhibited chlorophyll degradation and carotenoid accumulation, down-regulated key chlorophyll metabolism genes (CLH1, PPH, RCCR), and improved tomato quality metrics like hardness, brightness, and reduced weight loss.
population_specificity: Postharvest tomatoes
effective_dosage: 0 kV, 40 kV, 60 kV, and 80 kV ACP treatments
study_duration: During storage time (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Dubas bug infestation on chlorophyll content, palm biomass, and nutritional composition in date palms, as well as relationships between pest density, honeydew production, and oviposition.
results_summary: The study found that Dubas bug infestations reduced chlorophyll content by 8-11% and plant biomass by 29-34% at high pest densities. Increased pest density also led to reduced oviposition and altered nutrient levels (Ca, Mg, K, P), with Mg linked to chlorophyll reduction.
population_specificity: Date palm seedlings infested with Dubas bugs (Ommatissus lybicus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the combined effects of zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnONPs) and melatonin (MT) on chlorophyll content, growth, and cadmium (Cd) uptake in wheat plants.
results_summary: The study found that ZnONPs increased chlorophyll content, growth, and yield in wheat, with further enhancement when combined with MT. The treatments also reduced Cd concentration and increased zinc (Zn) concentration in plant tissues.
population_specificity: Wheat plants (Triticum aestivum L.) grown in Cd-polluted soil.
effective_dosage: 50 and 100 mg/kg ZnONPs (soil applied); 100 μM MT (foliar applied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular mechanism of BcGRP23 and its role in chlorophyll metabolism and the BES1 signaling pathway in flowering Chinese cabbage.
results_summary: BcGRP23 regulated chlorophyll degradation-related genes, affecting chlorophyll content, and its expression was significantly upregulated by brassinosteroid (BR) treatment and directly activated by BES1. Silencing BcGRP23 reduced chlorophyll a and b levels, while overexpression had the opposite effect.
population_specificity: Flowering Chinese cabbage plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the physiological responses of different Malus species to salt stress to aid in breeding salt-tolerant dwarfing apple rootstocks.
results_summary: The study found that Malus zumi was the most salt-resistant, showing minimal malondialdehyde (MDA) increase and high enzyme activity, while Malus baccata was the most sensitive, with significant MDA increases. Osmotic regulation and enzymatic antioxidants played key roles in mitigating salt stress across the species.
population_specificity: Seedlings of Malus zumi, Malus sieversii, and Malus baccata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how different winter wheat genotypes adapt their photosynthetic apparatus (including chlorophyll function) to physiological drought conditions.
results_summary: The study found that drought significantly affected photosynthetic efficiency and energy fluxes in winter wheat seedlings, with genotype-specific responses. Fluorescence parameters were useful for detecting drought impact, and four distinct genotype clusters were identified based on their reactions to drought.
population_specificity: Winter wheat seedlings (plant study, not human)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nitric oxide (NO) and spermidine (Spd) could mitigate the damaging effects of nickel (Ni) toxicity on chlorophyll metabolism, photosynthesis, and mineral content in tomato plants.
results_summary: Ni toxicity significantly reduced chlorophyll and carotenoid content, but NO and Spd application alleviated these declines, improved photosynthesis, reduced oxidative stress, and enhanced antioxidant activity. The combined supplementation of NO and Spd was particularly effective in mitigating Ni-induced damage.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) exposed to nickel toxicity.
effective_dosage: Nitric oxide (50 µM), spermidine (100 µM), and nickel (1 mM NiSO4·6H2O).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Azotobacter inoculation on photosynthesis and chlorophyll fluorescence in Iranian licorice plants under salt stress.
results_summary: Bacterial inoculation increased carotenoid levels by 28.3% compared to non-inoculated plants and improved chlorophyll fluorescence parameters (Fv, Fm, Fv/Fm) in certain accessions. Salinity reduced stomatal density but increased trichome density, while bacterial inoculation mitigated these stress effects.
population_specificity: Iranian licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra L.) plants (16 accessions) under NaCl stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Sclerospora graminicola infection affects chlorophyll synthesis and photosynthesis in foxtail millet leaves.
results_summary: The study found that S. graminicola infection significantly reduced chlorophyll and carotenoid content, disrupted chloroplast structure, and down-regulated genes related to chlorophyll synthesis and photosynthesis, leading to weakened photosynthesis and plant defense responses.
population_specificity: Foxtail millet plants (variety JG21) infected with S. graminicola.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if β-cyclocitral, a derivative of β-carotene oxidation, influences retrograde signaling and chlorophyll synthesis in the alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, similar to its role in Arabidopsis thaliana.
results_summary: The study found that β-cyclocitral down-regulated genes associated with chlorophyll synthesis in C. reinhardtii but did not contribute to singlet oxygen-mediated stress signaling, unlike in A. thaliana. The overlap in gene expression between β-cyclocitral-treated and singlet oxygen-treated algae was minimal.
population_specificity: Unicellular alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop multifunctional nanoparticles (Fe3O4@Chl/Fe CNPs) using iron chlorophyll to enhance programmed cell death and immunoactivation for bladder cancer treatment.
results_summary: The nanoparticles demonstrated combined photodynamic-chemodynamic therapy (PDT-CDT) effects, inducing ROS production, ferroptosis, and reprogramming the tumor microenvironment to improve antitumor efficacy, increasing survival rates from 0 to 91.7%.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer model (specific human or animal population not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of the insecticide dimethoate on the growth and photosynthetic activity of wheat seedlings, including chlorophyll fluorescence and pigment content.
results_summary: Lower doses of dimethoate (25 and 50 ppm) initially stimulated growth and photosynthetic activity in wheat seedlings after 10 days, but all concentrations became inhibitory with longer treatment durations (20 and 30 days). Higher doses (>50 ppm) consistently showed toxic effects.
population_specificity: Wheat seedlings (Triticum aestivum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photoactivity and Cu2+ adsorption selectivity of Chlorophyll-copper-modified ZnO nanorods (ChlCu/ZnO) and their potential for colorimetric detection of Cu2+.
results_summary: The study found that appropriate EDTA treatment improved the photoactivity and Cu2+ adsorption selectivity of ChlCu/ZnO, with optimal results achieved after 8 h of ChlCu treatment and 2 h of EDTA treatment. The modified E-ChlCu/ZnO exhibited excellent detection selectivity, a wide linear range (0-15 μM), and a low detection limit (0.024 μM) for Cu2+.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Treatment durations: 8 h for ChlCu, 2 h for EDTA

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two adjuvants (methylated seed oil and organosilicone) on the efficacy of topramezone herbicide under different temperature conditions, using chlorophyll fluorescence as a measurement.
results_summary: Methylated seed oil (MSO) significantly enhanced the efficacy of topramezone on giant foxtail and velvetleaf weeds by reducing chlorophyll fluorescence (Fv/Fm) under all tested temperature conditions, while organosilicone showed no significant difference compared to topramezone alone. The results aligned with traditional whole-plant bioassay methods.
population_specificity: Grassy weed species (giant foxtail) and broadleaved weed species (velvetleaf).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Zn2+ synergistic high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) treatment could improve chlorophyll stability, color quality, antioxidant activity, and thermal stability in green leafy vegetables.
results_summary: The study found that increasing zinc acetate concentration and HHP pressure improved color (-a* value), antioxidant activity (ABTS, DPPH, FRAP), and Zn2+ replacement rate, while maintaining chlorophyll structure. Optimal results were achieved at 10 mg/100 mL zinc acetate and 500 MPa HHP, significantly enhancing thermal stability.
population_specificity: Green leafy vegetables (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a non-toxic, antibacterial strategy using chlorophyll incorporated into polylactic acid (PLA) surfaces to combat bacterial infections without drug resistance or cytotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that chlorophyll exhibited excellent photodynamic bactericidal properties under non-toxic visible light and was incorporated into PLA surfaces, achieving efficient antibacterial activity with low bacterial adhesion and no toxicity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial growth on material surfaces).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 85% dark chocolate could improve vascular function and nitric oxide levels during high-intensity resistance exercise in healthy women across different menstrual phases.
results_summary: Dark chocolate significantly increased nitric oxide levels, reduced systolic blood pressure, arterial stiffness, and arterial pressure volume index compared to milk chocolate, with particularly notable benefits during the early follicular phase.
population_specificity: Healthy women aged 20-30 years with regular menstrual cycles.
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg body weight of 85% dark chocolate or milk chocolate, consumed before exercise.
study_duration: Two menstrual cycles (early follicular and mid-luteal phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term dark chocolate supplementation could enhance cognitive and physical performance and reduce delayed-onset muscle soreness in female CrossFit athletes across different menstrual phases.
results_summary: Dark chocolate significantly improved functional performance across all menstrual phases, with the greatest enhancement during PMS, and reduced DOMS in the luteal phase. It also improved reaction time during PMS, but no significant effects were observed on handgrip strength.
population_specificity: Fifteen trained eumenorrheic female CrossFit athletes.
study_duration: Three consecutive menstrual cycles (each phase tested over three days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immune-modulatory effects of cocoa-rich dark chocolate and its bioactive compounds on various inflammatory conditions.
results_summary: Dark chocolate and its derivatives were found to reduce pro-inflammatory responses in vascular, metabolic, and chronic diseases, enhance gut barrier function, and modulate pain, but worsened acne symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with vascular diseases (atherosclerosis, hypertension, decompression sickness), metabolic morbidities (obesity, type 2 diabetes), celiac disease, chronic kidney diseases, and polycystic ovary syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Chocolate balloon use combined with DCB angioplasty versus plain balloons for treating femoropopliteal lesions.
results_summary: Chocolate balloon use did not significantly improve primary patency or reduce flow-limiting dissection rates but reduced bailout stenting length, particularly in complex lesions.
population_specificity: 192 patients (197 de-novo femoropopliteal lesions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate clinical effects of chocolate balloons versus conventional balloons in endovascular angioplasty for lower limb arterial lesions.
results_summary: Chocolate balloons showed a lower incidence of severe dissection (5.8% vs. 12.7%) and reduced stent implantation rates (9.0% vs. 18.3%) compared to conventional balloons, with statistically significant differences.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb arterial lesions (117 in 2021, 112 in 2023).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether 70% cocoa dark chocolate intake could improve magnesium (Mg2+) serum levels in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) on hemodialysis.
results_summary: The study found that 40g of 70% cocoa dark chocolate consumed three times a week for two months significantly increased Mg2+ serum levels in CKD patients on hemodialysis, without altering potassium or phosphorus levels. No significant differences were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) undergoing hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: 40g of 70% cocoa chocolate, three times a week during hemodialysis sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of chocolate balloons versus conventional balloons in treating chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) and infrapopliteal artery disease.
results_summary: Chocolate balloons showed a significantly higher rate of avoiding lesion revascularization (84.0% vs. 69.4%) and reduced flow-limiting dissection and stent implantation compared to conventional balloons, but no significant benefit in amputation-free survival or major amputation reduction.
population_specificity: 167 patients with CLTI and infrapopliteal artery disease.
study_duration: Follow-up at 30 days, 6 months, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming 78% dark chocolate compared to milk chocolate could improve depression scores, sleep quality, and anthropometric indices in menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that dark chocolate significantly reduced depression scores compared to milk chocolate, but no significant differences were observed in sleep quality or anthropometric indices between the two groups.
population_specificity: Menopausal women aged 45-65

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and analyze a mathematical model to determine the best strategy for controlling Chocolate Spot Disease (CSD) in faba bean plants.
results_summary: The study found that integrated strategies, particularly prevention and uprooting, were cost-effective in reducing CSD. Numerical simulations confirmed that each integrated strategy could reduce disease spread within a specified period.
population_specificity: Faba bean plants affected by Chocolate Spot Disease (Botrytis fabae).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess retail conditions, challenges, and retailers' willingness to use cooling devices to maintain chocolate quality in supply chains.
results_summary: The study found that most retailers faced challenges like chocolate softening, spoilage, and surface defects due to elevated temperatures, with 81.1% willing to use cooling devices to mitigate these issues. Retail conditions were generally unsuitable for chocolate shelf-stability.
population_specificity: 228 chocolate retailers in Kumasi and Accra, predominantly female (82%), aged 21-30 (33.9%), with limited education (39.0% max Junior High School).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize exposures to mushroom-containing chocolate products, including patient characteristics, clinical effects, treatments, and clinical outcome severity.
results_summary: The study found that most patients experienced minor clinical effects like mental status changes and gastrointestinal discomfort, but some developed serious effects such as seizures and dysrhythmias. No fatalities were reported, and effects typically lasted 3-24 hours.
population_specificity: Patients exposed to mushroom-containing chocolate products (median age 17 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dry cleaning methods in removing milk chocolate residue from equipment to prevent cross-contact in dark chocolate production.
results_summary: The study found that dark chocolate push-through alone was insufficient to reduce milk concentrations below detectable levels, while pig purging and cocoa butter flushes were effective in reducing milk contamination. Some dry cleaning methods significantly reduced milk levels in dark chocolate, with cocoa butter rinses reducing contamination by ≥89%.
population_specificity: Not specified (industrial chocolate production equipment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of probiotic chocolate containing Lactobacillus plantarum Dad-13 on gut microbiota diversity, short-chain fatty acid levels, and fecal pH in undernourished children.
results_summary: The probiotic chocolate significantly altered gut microbiota diversity and fecal pH, with higher Bacteroidetes in the probiotic group and higher Firmicutes in the placebo group. Differences were also observed at the genus level, including Bifidobacterium and Prevotella.
population_specificity: Undernourished children in Lombok (n=56, split into probiotic and placebo groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effectiveness and safety of combining drug-coated balloon (DCB) with a Chocolate balloon catheter for treating femoropopliteal artery lesions.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of DCB and Chocolate balloon angioplasty achieved high primary patency rates (78.7% at 12 months) and freedom from target lesion revascularization (85.1% at 12 months), with significant improvements in ankle-brachial index and Rutherford classification. However, dissection occurred in 72.3% of limbs, though most were mild.
population_specificity: Patients with femoropopliteal artery lesions (Rutherford classification 2-6), mean age 72.84 years, 67.4% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dark chocolate/cocoa on oxidative stress and inflammation biomarkers in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis of controlled trials.
results_summary: Dark chocolate/cocoa significantly reduced malondialdehyde (MDA) and increased nitric oxide (NO) levels but had no significant effects on other inflammation biomarkers. Greater anti-inflammatory effects were observed at higher flavonoid doses (>450 mg/day) and shorter durations (≤4 weeks) in non-healthy participants.
population_specificity: Adults (1379 participants across 33 studies)
effective_dosage: Varied (cocoa powder, beverages, chocolate bars; higher efficacy at >450 mg/day flavonoids)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of dark chocolate and carrot juice on perceived labor pain during stage 1 of birth delivery among primigravida.
results_summary: The study found that both dark chocolate and carrot juice independently reduced labor pain in primigravida mothers, with significant interaction between group and time. The therapies were deemed viable for advanced labor pain.
population_specificity: Primigravida mothers in stage 1 of labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether optimizing nitrogen fertilizer application in wheat/faba bean intercropping could enhance faba bean productivity and control chocolate spot disease.
results_summary: The study found that optimized nitrogen fertilizer (N2 treatment) improved faba bean productivity and reduced chocolate spot disease severity, with intercropping showing better disease control and yield benefits compared to single cropping. Higher nitrogen levels (N3) reduced harvest index, indicating a threshold for optimal fertilizer use.
population_specificity: Faba bean crops intercropped with wheat in field conditions.
effective_dosage: N1, N2, and N3 nitrogen fertilizer treatments (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Two planting seasons (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health effects of consuming enriched, fortified, or supplemented chocolate, focusing on its potential benefits for cardiovascular health, metabolic function, and immune response.
results_summary: Some enriched chocolates reduced total and LDL cholesterol and influenced markers of oxidative damage, inflammation, immune function, and skin parameters, while other trials showed minimal impact on health outcomes. The findings suggest promise but require further rigorous investigation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the stabilizing effect of bioemulsifiers/biosurfactants (BE/BS) from two lactobacilli strains in cold chocolate milk drinks.
results_summary: BE/BS from L. brevis S4 and L. plantarum S5 showed stable emulsifying and surface activities, antimicrobial effects, and successfully stabilized cold chocolate milk drinks at 0.2% (w/v).
population_specificity: Not specified (general chocolate milk drink consumers implied).
study_duration: Stability assessed for 72 hours at room temperature.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the causal relationship between dark chocolate intake and the risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) using Mendelian randomization.
results_summary: The study found that dark chocolate intake was significantly associated with a reduced risk of essential hypertension and a suggestive association with reduced risk of venous thromboembolism, but no association was found with ten other CVDs.
population_specificity: General population (data derived from genome-wide association studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining vitamin E and chocolate polyphenols with a protein-rich diet and exercise could prevent age-related muscle mass loss and improve mitochondrial function in predementia elderly individuals.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results, as the trial was launched in 2020 and outcomes (muscle mass, neurocognitive status, and biomolecular indices) were not yet available at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Predementia older people (n=75)
effective_dosage: 30 g/day of dark chocolate containing 500 mg total polyphenols (60 mg epicatechin) and 100 mg vitamin E (RRR-alpha-tocopherol)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intercropping faba beans in controlling chocolate spot disease and its contribution to yield increase under nitrogen input.
results_summary: Intercropping reduced chocolate spot disease progression by 32.4-51.0% compared to monoculture, while nitrogen input increased disease severity. Intercropping with nitrogen treatment (45-90 kg ha-1) maximized disease control and yield benefits.
population_specificity: Faba bean-wheat intercropping systems at two experimental sites (EShan and Xundian).
effective_dosage: Nitrogen input levels of 45-90 kg ha-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dark chocolate against green coconut water and Ibuprofen in reducing pain intensity in primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The study found that dark chocolate was less effective than Ibuprofen but provided some pain relief for primary dysmenorrhea, as indicated by the Kruskal-Wallis test results.
population_specificity: 45 women experiencing primary dysmenorrhea.
effective_dosage: 35 g of 70% dark chocolate, single dose.
study_duration: Single administration on the first day of menstruation, with pain measured 2 hours post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to diagnose and describe a rare case of pseudochylothorax with a chocolate-colored pleural effusion, not to evaluate chocolate's safety or efficacy.
results_summary: The study identified a chocolate-colored pleural effusion as a diagnostic clue for pseudochylothorax, with biochemical analysis confirming high cholesterol levels. The patient's symptoms improved after thoracentesis.
population_specificity: A 55-year-old woman with a history of pleuropulmonary tuberculosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of chronic chocolate consumption on cognitive function in healthy adults by analyzing published randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Chronic chocolate intake significantly improved executive function and language performance, reducing executive function time by 11.77 units and increasing language and executive function by 6.38 times. The study concluded that daily cocoa consumption may enhance cognitive performance in learning, memory, and attention in young adults.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (young adults specifically mentioned in the conclusion)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if blood powder (BP) pre-treated by grinding and gamma irradiation could serve as a cost-effective alternative to defibrinated blood in manufacturing Chocolate agar (CA) for bacterial culture.
results_summary: The study found that CA prepared with ground and gamma-irradiated BP performed similarly to conventional CA in supporting bacterial growth, particularly for fastidious species, while being more economical. The medium with only irradiated BP showed reduced growth for fastidious bacteria.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (fastidious and non-fastidious species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of the Chocolate Touch drug-coated balloon (DCB) versus the Lutonix DCB for treating femoropopliteal artery lesions, specifically analyzing outcomes in patients with and without diabetes mellitus (DM).
results_summary: The study found that the Chocolate Touch DCB had superior efficacy (77.2% vs. 60.5% in DM patients; 80% vs. 71.3% in non-DM patients) compared to the Lutonix DCB, though statistical significance was not reached in the DM subgroup. Safety outcomes were similar for both DCBs regardless of DM status.
population_specificity: Patients with claudication or ischemic rest pain (Rutherford class 2-4) undergoing treatment for femoropopliteal artery lesions, including those with (38%) and without diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of phenolic acids (SA, OA, NA, BA) in mitigating chocolate spot disease and enhancing the defense system in Vicia faba plants.
results_summary: All tested chemical inducers significantly reduced disease severity, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, and improved plant tissue recovery. SA (5 mM) showed the most pronounced effects on plant tissue thickness.
population_specificity: Vicia faba (faba bean) plants infected by Botrytis fabae.
effective_dosage: SA (5 mM), other phenolic acids (concentration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dark chocolate on inflammation and oxidative stress markers in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) on hemodialysis.
results_summary: Dark chocolate (70% cocoa) reduced plasma levels of TNF-α but did not significantly affect oxidative stress markers. It also did not increase phosphorus or potassium levels in CKD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: 40g of dark chocolate (70% cocoa) offered during HD sessions, 3×/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of long-term acclimation to different water temperatures on oxidative stress, metabolic stress, and heat shock protein expression in chocolate mahseer (Neolissochilus hexagonolepis).
results_summary: The study found that acclimation to extreme temperatures (15°C and 31°C) modulated antioxidant transcripts, enzymes, and heat shock proteins in chocolate mahseer, with varying effects on oxidative and metabolic stress markers.
population_specificity: Chocolate mahseer (Neolissochilus hexagonolepis) larvae.

study_goal: The study does not address Chocolate; it explores the experiences and needs of people with Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA) and their communication partners in relation to speech and language therapy (SLT).
results_summary: The study does not examine Chocolate; it identifies key themes such as communication difficulties, caregiver burden, and the need for person-centered SLT approaches for PPA patients and their families.
population_specificity: People with Primary Progressive Aphasia (PwPPA) and their communication partners (CPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the protective effect of dark chocolate on a letrozole-induced rat model of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Dark chocolate treatment significantly improved PCOS signs, restored ovarian morphology and function, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and improved oxidative/antioxidative status compared to the letrozole group.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats (200 ± 20 g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of milk and dark chocolate on heart failure by measuring endothelial functions and biomarkers.
results_summary: Both milk and dark chocolate significantly reduced N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide levels, while dark chocolate also improved endothelial function by increasing flow-mediated dilation values.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of chocolate and cocoa (or derived molecules) in the elderly, focusing on their potential to manage cognitive decline.
results_summary: The review found that cocoa biomolecules may offer promising tools for managing cognitive decline when provided in adequate dosages and treatment durations, though the molecular mechanisms remain incompletely understood. The evidence included 9 observational and 10 interventional studies, suggesting potential benefits but requiring further research.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those at risk of or experiencing cognitive decline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of Chocolate percutaneous transluminal angioplasty balloons versus conventional balloons on vessel preparation in femoropopliteal lesions during drug-coated balloon angioplasty.
results_summary: Chocolate balloons significantly reduced severe dissection rates (4.2% vs. 25%) and bailout stenting (2.1% vs. 15.9%) compared to conventional balloons, while maintaining similar angiographic and patency outcomes at six months.
population_specificity: Patients with femoropopliteal lesions undergoing endovascular therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (balloon length and inflation pressure varied: 90 ± 37 mm at 11 ± 3 atm for Chocolate vs. 149 ± 95 mm at 16 ± 7 atm for conventional).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential benefits of caffeine and its derivatives, including theobromine (found in chocolate), in reducing the risk and modifying the progression of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The review found that caffeine and its derivatives, such as theobromine, are associated with a reduced risk of Parkinson's disease and may reduce excitotoxicity caused by glutamate. A2A receptor antagonism by these compounds shows promise as a disease-modifying target in Parkinson's disease.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease and animal models of the disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of high-pressure processing (HPP) on the long-term storage stability of dark chocolate fillings compared to conventional low-temperature storage.
results_summary: HPP at 600 MPa/20 min effectively controlled microbial growth, inactivating molds and yeasts, while storage affected color and rheological properties but not moisture, water activity, or pH.
population_specificity: Dark chocolate fillings (no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of the Chocolate Touch drug-coated balloon (DCB) versus the Lutonix DCB for treating femoropopliteal disease in patients with claudication or ischemic rest pain.
results_summary: The Chocolate Touch DCB demonstrated superior efficacy (78.8% success rate) compared to Lutonix DCB (67.7%) at 12 months, meeting noninferiority and superiority for efficacy but not for safety. Safety outcomes were comparable between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with claudication or ischemic rest pain (Rutherford class 2-4) and superficial femoral or popliteal disease (≥70% stenosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the health-related effects of microencapsulated fermented garlic extract (FGE) containing dark chocolate on hypertensive adults, focusing on blood pressure, lipid profile, and oxidative stress indices.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in blood pressure, lipid profile, or oxidative stress indices after 6 weeks of consuming FGE-containing dark chocolate, suggesting the dosage used was insufficient to produce measurable effects.
population_specificity: 36 hypertensive adults (15 males, 21 females).
effective_dosage: 5 g/day of dark chocolate containing 650 mg of FGE powder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-fat chocolate milk (LFCM) consumption could reduce delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) and improve performance metrics in female badminton players.
results_summary: LFCM consumption significantly improved aerobic power, anaerobic power, explosive power, and time to exhaustion while reducing perceived exertion and muscle soreness compared to placebo. No significant changes were observed in agility or maximum handgrip strength.
population_specificity: Seven female badminton players (aged 23 ± 1 years).
effective_dosage: 500 mL immediately after each training session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 4 weeks of chocolate consumption (55% cocoa vs. white chocolate) on the nutritional status and quality of life of older cancer patients in palliative care.
results_summary: Consumption of 55% cocoa chocolate improved nutritional status and functionality, while white chocolate was associated with reduced oxidative stress markers. No significant changes were observed in anthropometry or body composition.
population_specificity: Older cancer patients in palliative care with ambulatory monitoring.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only cocoa percentages provided: 55% cocoa chocolate and white chocolate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining dark chocolate consumption with jump rope exercise improves antioxidant markers more effectively than either intervention alone in obese adolescent boys.
results_summary: The study found that combining dark chocolate consumption with jump rope exercise significantly increased antioxidant markers (TAC, SOD, GPx) and reduced oxidative stress (TBARS) more than dark chocolate or exercise alone. The JD group showed the most significant improvements compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Obese adolescent boys (age 15 ± 1 years).
effective_dosage: 30 g of dark chocolate (83% cocoa) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of chocolate consumption on cardiovascular health, particularly atherosclerosis, by reviewing recent reports on its benefits and adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that chocolate, when consumed in optimal amounts (30-50 g), has cardiovascular benefits due to phenolic compounds with anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antiplatelet properties, though some evidence remains controversial. The GRADE scale did not confirm these benefits, and effects varied by factors like age, sex, and medical conditions.
population_specificity: General population, with specific dosage recommendations for women and men.
interactions: Risk of pharmacologically relevant interactions with cardiovascular drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a saikosaponin-enriched extract from Bupleurum falcatum roots on reducing chocolate self-administration in rats.
results_summary: Acute treatment with B. falcatum extract reduced chocolate self-administration in a dose-related manner, suggesting potential anorectic effects. The results support the extract's anti-addictive and appetite-suppressing properties.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats trained to self-administer chocolate (5% w/v powdered Nesquik in water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical features and outcomes of dogs after chocolate ingestion, focusing on toxicity and treatment efficacy.
results_summary: Most dogs (112/156) showed no clinical signs after chocolate ingestion, but 44 exhibited symptoms like agitation, tachycardia, and vomiting. Treatment (decontamination and symptomatic therapy) was effective, with a survival rate of 97.7%.
population_specificity: Dogs (156 cases)
effective_dosage: Not specified (amount calculated based on chocolate type and ingested quantity)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the remineralization effects of a ginger-honey-chocolate mixture and its individual components (including bitter chocolate) on initial enamel caries lesions.
results_summary: The study found that all groups, including bitter chocolate, showed enhanced remineralization, with no significant differences between groups in terms of surface microhardness recovery or mineral changes. The herbal components (ginger, honey, and bitter chocolate) demonstrated high remineralization potential.
population_specificity: Enamel caries lesion specimens (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 1 min interaction with agent/deionized slurries (1:3 w/w) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of cocoa shell (CS) as a green adsorbent for removing cationic dye (BB41) from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa shell effectively adsorbed BB41 dye (90.04% removal) under mild conditions, primarily through electrostatic interactions, π-π stacking, hydrogen bonding, and physical mechanisms. The process was non-spontaneous and endothermic, with an activation energy of 18.28 kJ/mol.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on cocoa shell as an adsorbent).
effective_dosage: 4 g/L of cocoa shell, 10 mg/L BB41 concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of thunder-fire moxibustion combined with mifepristone for treating ovarian chocolate cyst dysmenorrhea in patients with kidney deficiency and blood stasis.
results_summary: The combination therapy significantly improved dysmenorrhea symptoms, reduced cyst size, and lowered serum levels of TGF-β1 and IL-17, with the observation group showing superior results compared to the control group (94.3% vs. 71.4% effectiveness).
population_specificity: 70 patients with ovarian chocolate cyst dysmenorrhea and kidney deficiency/blood stasis.
effective_dosage: Mifepristone (10 mg once daily); thunder-fire moxibustion (every other day at specific acupoints).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between chocolate consumption and metabolic syndrome (MetS) in Korean adults, focusing on lifestyle factors and dietary patterns.
results_summary: Chocolate consumers exhibited healthier lifestyles, dietary patterns, and a 30% lower risk of MetS compared to non-consumers, though no dose-response effect was found among consumers. The study suggests chocolate consumption does not increase MetS risk.
population_specificity: 6,982 Korean adults aged 19-64 years without major chronic diseases.
effective_dosage: Quartile-based consumption (Q1-Q4), exact amounts not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the chocolate matrix affects the absorption and plasma profiles of green tea catechins (GTCs) in humans and rats.
results_summary: The chocolate matrix reduced plasma concentrations of ECg and EGCg but not EC and EGC in humans. ECg persisted longer in plasma than EGCg, regardless of the chocolate matrix, and was detected after daily intake in humans and rats.
population_specificity: Five healthy 22-year-old women and nine rats.
study_duration: 14 days for daily intake in humans and rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for simultaneously detecting cadmium, lead, and copper levels in chocolate samples using Square Wave Anodic Stripping Voltammetry (SWASV).
results_summary: The study found efficient extraction (~100%) of metals after 1 hour of ultrasonic pre-treatment, with good linearity, precision, and accuracy. Concentrations in chocolate samples ranged from 4.30-138 µg g-1 for Cu and 0.83-27.9 µg g-1 for Pb, with no significant Cd detected.
population_specificity: Chocolate samples (14 varieties).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming cocoa-rich chocolate significantly affects lipid profiles and anthropometric variables compared to placebo in the Colombian population.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in lipid profiles (total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, triglycerides) or anthropometric variables (abdominal circumference, body mass index) between the cocoa and placebo groups. The conclusion had weak recommendation strength and low-to-moderate certainty.
population_specificity: Colombian adults (52.7% female, 275 participants, few smokers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the elemental composition of different types of chocolate and compare the effectiveness of sample pre-treatment methods.
results_summary: The study found that macro- and microelement levels in chocolate vary by type, with P being the most abundant macroelement and Fe the highest among essential microelements. Toxic metals like Ba, Al, and Sr were detected but did not exceed permissible safety limits.
population_specificity: Chocolate samples from the Polish market, including dark, milk, white chocolate, and 100% cocoa powder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on the relationship and effects of cocoa and dark chocolate intake among obese adults, focusing on obesity management and metabolic disease prevention.
results_summary: The review found inconsistent results regarding the effects of cocoa and dark chocolate on obesity, likely due to variations in study populations, cocoa product types, and dosages. More research is needed to clarify the role of cocoa polyphenols in weight control and chronic disease prevention, especially in obese individuals without comorbidities.
population_specificity: Obese adults, particularly those with comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of dark chocolate intake on blood pressure and the integration of mHealth technologies in a clinical trial.
results_summary: The study found that 2 weeks of dark chocolate consumption did not significantly reduce resting systolic blood pressure. Additionally, mHealth devices showed poor agreement with standard blood pressure measurements.
population_specificity: 62 healthy volunteers (mean age 37 years; 61% female).
effective_dosage: 50 g of dark chocolate per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding 10 g of cocoa-rich chocolate (99%) to the habitual diet improves cognitive performance in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found a slight improvement in cognitive flexibility and processing speed (Trail Making Test B) but no changes in attention, verbal memory, working memory, or fluency. The effect size was small (Cohen's d = -0.343).
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-64.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining dark chocolate supplementation with interval jump rope exercise could reduce obesity-induced inflammation and improve body composition in obese adolescent boys.
results_summary: The study found that dark chocolate supplementation combined with jump rope exercise significantly improved body composition, reduced pro-inflammatory markers, and increased anti-inflammatory adipokines, with the greatest effects observed in the combined intervention group.
population_specificity: Obese adolescent boys (age 15.4 ± 1.1 years, BMI 32.2 ± 2.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 30 g of dark chocolate (83% cocoa) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chocolate milk, alone and combined with HIIT, on appetite and cognitive performance in youth.
results_summary: Chocolate milk consumption reduced subjective appetite compared to water and increased blood glucose levels. No adverse effects were reported, but safety was not a primary focus.
population_specificity: Youth aged 9-13 years (12 girls, 8 boys).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating rare complications (chocolate cysts) associated with porous polyethylene implants used in orbital fracture repair, not the safety or efficacy of chocolate as a consumable product.
results_summary: The study found that chocolate cysts can develop years after orbital fracture repair with porous polyethylene implants, requiring surgical intervention for symptom relief. One case showed orbital volume expansion due to the cyst.
population_specificity: Patients with late-onset orbital hemorrhage (chocolate cysts) following orbital fracture repair with porous polyethylene implants (3 cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding 10 g per day of cocoa-rich chocolate (99% cocoa) to the habitual diet of postmenopausal women for 6 months would improve their quality of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in global quality of life scores (EuroQoL-5D-3L or Cervantes scale) but observed a slight improvement in health perception (EQ-VAS) in the intervention group compared to controls. The effect was modest and did not translate to broader quality-of-life dimensions.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-64 years (n = 140).
effective_dosage: 10 g per day of 99% cocoa chocolate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding 10 g of cocoa-rich chocolate daily to the habitual diet of postmenopausal women affects body composition.
results_summary: The study found that daily consumption of 10 g of cocoa-rich chocolate significantly reduced body fat mass and body fat percentage in postmenopausal women, with no significant change in BMI. The effects were consistent across trunk, arms, and legs.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (average age 57.2 years, n=132).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how natron reduces the bitterness of cocoa cake and its effect on the nutritive value of different chocolate types.
results_summary: Natron significantly reduced bitterness and improved taste and overall acceptability of chocolates. It also altered nutritional content, decreasing phenolic compounds, moisture, lipids, ash, and energy while increasing carbohydrates, fiber, sodium, and iron.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general chocolate consumers).
effective_dosage: 0 g, 0.961 g, 1.082 g, 1.202 g, 1.322 g, and 1.442 g of natron per 200 g of cocoa cake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of two decontamination methods (PAA-ethanol sanitizer and AOP) in reducing Salmonella and Listeria monocytogenes on low-moisture foods, including chocolate crumb.
results_summary: The study found that no Salmonella was detected on chocolate crumb when treated with 1.25‰ PAA-ethanol sanitizer. L. monocytogenes was more sensitive to PAA-ethanol and could be eliminated from all low-moisture foods except shell-on pistachio.
population_specificity: Model low-moisture foods (including chocolate crumb) inoculated with Salmonella or L. monocytogenes.
effective_dosage: 1.25‰ PAA-ethanol sanitizer, 2.5‰ PAA-ethanol sanitizer, 5.0‰ PAA-ethanol sanitizer, and AOP treatment with 10% v/v hydrogen peroxide, ozone, and 54 mJ/cm² UV-C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of daily 10 g cocoa-rich chocolate intake on blood pressure, cardiovascular risk factors, and vascular structure/function in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in systolic blood pressure or most vascular parameters, except for a modest decrease in pulse pressure. Cocoa-rich chocolate showed no adverse effects on the evaluated parameters.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n = 140)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocoa flavanols in dark chocolate improve cognitive functions, blood lipids, and glucose metabolism in cognitively healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cognitive function, blood lipids, glucose levels, or body weight between the intervention group (higher flavanol intake) and the control group (lower flavanol intake) after eight weeks.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy older adults aged 65-75 years, highly educated (mean 14.9 years of education).
effective_dosage: 50 g dark chocolate per day (intervention group: 410 mg flavanols; control group: 86 mg flavanols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saikosaponins from Bupleurum falcatum, other than saikosaponin A (SSA), could reduce chocolate self-administration in rats.
results_summary: Only SSA and its epimer SSD reduced chocolate self-administration, while other saikosaponins (SSC, SSB2, SSB4) were ineffective. The study suggests structural differences in saikosaponins significantly impact their efficacy in reducing addictive-like behaviors.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Wistar rats trained to self-administer a chocolate solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining food-inhibition association training with high-frequency rTMS could reduce impulsive chocolate snack intake in healthy young adults.
results_summary: No-go training reduced chocolate intake compared to go training, but not neutral training. Combined rTMS and no-go training further reduced intake compared to neutral training, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for overeating.
population_specificity: Healthy young adult female volunteers (BMI range 15-31).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of dark chocolate and flavonoids on flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) through randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Chronic and acute consumption of dark chocolate and flavonoids significantly improved FMD, with non-linear dose-response relationships observed. The highest FMD improvement was seen at doses of 40-60 g/day for flavonoids and doses below 20 g/day for dark chocolate.
population_specificity: 615 participants across 17 studies for dark chocolate, and 179 participants across 6 studies for flavonoids.
effective_dosage: Flavonoids more than 40 g/day, dark chocolate doses below 20 g/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming a commercially available dark chocolate bar could improve episodic verbal memory and mood compared to a white chocolate bar in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Dark chocolate consumption was associated with better verbal memory performance on several measures of the Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test compared to white chocolate, but no effects on mood were observed.
population_specificity: 98 healthy young adults (57 females) aged 18-24 years.
effective_dosage: 35 g of dark chocolate or white chocolate, consumed once.
study_duration: Single consumption with assessments pre and 2 hours post consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a smartphone-based approach-avoidance training could reduce chocolate craving and consumption in regular chocolate eaters.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in chocolate craving or consumption between intervention and control groups, with all groups showing similar reductions in self-reported craving, consumption, and body fat mass. The training did not provide additional benefits over measurement-based changes.
population_specificity: Regular chocolate eaters (n=105, 86% female).
effective_dosage: Five training sessions over 10 days (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the applicability of ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) for real-time process monitoring in chocolate manufacturing, specifically focusing on distinguishing processing steps based on conching temperature and time.
results_summary: The study found that IMS could distinguish different processing states of bulk cocoa based on flavor fingerprints, and principal component analysis (PCA) identified specific IM spectra regions affected by conching temperature and time, suggesting IMS could be useful for process control in cocoa processing.
population_specificity: Bulk cocoa during manufacturing processes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the cardiovascular benefits of chocolate, focusing on the effects of cocoa flavanols on endothelial function, inflammation, platelet aggregation, lipid oxidation, and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa flavanols improve endothelial vasodilation, reduce inflammatory markers, decrease platelet aggregation, lower lipid oxidation, and mitigate insulin resistance, supporting cardiovascular health.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of dark chocolate flavanols on subjective visual function and retinal perfusion objectively quantified via OCT angiography.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in retinal perfusion or subjective visual function after consumption of flavanol-rich dark chocolate compared to milk chocolate. No differences were observed in visual acuity or contrast sensitivity measures.
population_specificity: 22 healthy participants (13 women; mean age 27.3 years) from the Department of Ophthalmology, Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich, Germany.
effective_dosage: 20 g of dark chocolate containing 400 mg flavanols or 7.5 g milk chocolate, consumed once.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with measurements taken 2 hours post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal operating temperature for UASB reactors treating chocolate-processing industry wastewater at medium organic loading rates.
results_summary: The study found that reactors operating at 20, 25, and 30 °C achieved high and similar COD removal efficiencies (88-94%) and biogas production rates, while the 15 °C reactor performed significantly worse.
population_specificity: Laboratory-scale UASB reactors treating chocolate-processing wastewater.
effective_dosage: Organic loading rates of 2, 4, and 6 kg CODs/(m³ d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular benefits of long-term dark chocolate intake, comparing higher cocoa (90%) and lower cocoa (55%) chocolate in young, healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that higher cocoa chocolate (HCC) improved vascular function, reducing central brachial artery pressures and enhancing ventricular-arterial coupling, while lower cocoa chocolate (LCC) showed minimal effects. No structural heart changes were observed, but functional improvements were significant in the HCC group.
population_specificity: 30 healthy participants aged 18 to 27 years.
effective_dosage: 20 g daily of either higher cocoa (90%) or lower cocoa (55%) chocolate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dark chocolate enriched with EVOO or dry apples could improve circulating endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) levels in individuals with cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that EVOO-enriched dark chocolate significantly increased EPCs levels, a marker of endothelial function, while most biochemical parameters remained unchanged. Apple-enriched dark chocolate did not show significant effects.
population_specificity: 30 volunteers (26 completed) with cardiovascular risk factors (M/F:14/12, mean age 51 ± 9 years).
effective_dosage: 40 g/day of dark chocolate (10% EVOO or 2.5% dry apples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary polyphenol changes, including polyphenol-rich chocolate milk, could alter salivary protein expression and influence oral sensory perception.
results_summary: The study found that both almond and bovine chocolate milk interventions led to changes in salivary protein expression, particularly proline-rich proteins and cystatins, but sensory changes were minimal. Bovine chocolate milk was rated as less flavorful compared to low polyphenol weeks.
population_specificity: Human subjects (N=55)
study_duration: Alternating weeks of low polyphenol diet and regular diet plus chocolate milk

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of tDCS combined with a cognitive bias modification task could affect explicit and implicit measures of craving for chocolate.
results_summary: The study found that LARC tDCS increased both explicit and implicit craving for chocolate compared to RALC and Sham tDCS, suggesting a left-hemisphere dependency for chocolate craving.
population_specificity: 51 healthy volunteers (38 females; mean age: 22.12 ± 3.38).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether probiotic chocolate containing Streptococcus thermophilus MG510 and Lactobacillus plantarum LRCC5193 (LYC) could alleviate constipation in loperamide-induced constipated rats.
results_summary: The study found that LYC significantly increased defecation frequency, fecal moisture content, and beneficial gut bacteria (Lactobacillus and Faecalibacterium prausnitzii). It also improved colonic structure, intestinal motility, and modulated tight junction protein expression in constipated rats.
population_specificity: Loperamide-induced constipated rats (n=14 for defecation metrics, n=5 for motility, n=9 for mRNA analysis).
effective_dosage: Daily oral administration (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nitinol-structured (chocolate-like) drug-coated balloon (C-DEB PTA) in treating Takayasu arteritis (TA).
results_summary: The study found that a 63-year-old woman with TA who underwent C-DEB PTA remained in remission for over one year, suggesting potential efficacy for this treatment. The case may encourage further research into C-DEB PTA for TA.
population_specificity: A 63-year-old woman with Takayasu arteritis (TA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of daily high-cocoa chocolate intake on blood pressure, vascular function, cognitive performance, quality of life, and body composition in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results; it describes the study protocol and planned outcomes.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-64 with at least 12 months of amenorrhea.
effective_dosage: 10 g daily of 99% cocoa chocolate (59 kcal, 65.4 mg polyphenols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prophylactic effect of probiotic chocolate on constipation in rats.
results_summary: Probiotic chocolate significantly improved intestinal motility, colon length, fecal moisture content, and fecal pellet excretion in constipated rats. It also upregulated mRNA expression of colonic barrier proteins and modulated gut bacterial populations favorably.
population_specificity: Constipated rats induced by loperamide treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of regular high-cocoa chocolate consumption on arterial stiffness and fat oxidation during light- to moderate-intensity exercise.
results_summary: Four weeks of high-cocoa chocolate consumption significantly reduced arterial stiffness (measured by heart-ankle pulse wave velocity and cardio-ankle vascular index) but did not affect blood pressure, body composition, or metabolic characteristics during exercise.
population_specificity: 32 Japanese college students (mean age 20.7 ± 0.3 years; 24 men, 8 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dark chocolate on inflammatory markers, serum adiponectin, and biochemical factors in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Dark chocolate consumption significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, hemoglobin A1C, LDL, triglycerides, and inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, TNF-α, IL-6) in diabetic patients, though adiponectin levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the genoprotective effect and cardiovascular/metabolic benefits of flavonoids-rich dark chocolate in young volunteers.
results_summary: Dark chocolate (70% cocoa) significantly prevented DNA damage, improved nucleus integrity, and enhanced biochemical (cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL) and anthropometrical (waist circumference) parameters after six months of daily consumption.
population_specificity: 84 young volunteers
effective_dosage: 2 g daily (dark chocolate with 70% cocoa or milk chocolate)

study_goal: To determine if lycosome-formulated dark chocolate with astaxanthin improves astaxanthin bioavailability and affects markers of hypoxia and oxidative stress in aging individuals.
results_summary: The lycosomal formulation (L-DC-ASTX) showed a 40-fold increase in serum astaxanthin levels, more prominent reductions in oxidative stress markers, and synergistic effects on nitric oxide production and oxygen transport compared to other formulations.
population_specificity: 32 healthy individuals aged 60-70 years with confirmed oxidative stress markers.
effective_dosage: 10 g of dark chocolate (with or without 7 mg astaxanthin) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively characterize the phenolic profile of dark chocolate and explore the effects of enriching it with Sakura green tea leaves or turmeric powder.
results_summary: The study identified 158 phenolic compounds in dark chocolate, including 67 newly detected compounds, with ellagitannins representing 10% of the profile. Enrichment with green tea or turmeric increased phenolic concentration, potentially enhancing health benefits while reducing sugar and calorie content.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or analytical study implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how changes in skim milk powder (SMP) manufacturing processes affect its volatile profile and whether these changes influence the flavor of chocolate products like white chocolate.
results_summary: The study found that variations in SMP processing conditions (concentration, heat treatment, drying) altered the volatile profile of SMP, and these differences persisted in the final white chocolate product, impacting flavor.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study using model systems).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (processing conditions varied, not dosages).
study_duration: Not specified (focused on processing stages, not time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a Go/No Go training to food cue exposure would enhance its effects on reducing chocolate consumption in chocolate-loving female students.
results_summary: The study found that cue exposure increased desire to eat and salivation compared to the control group, but the Go/No Go training did not enhance these effects. There were no differences in chocolate or snack intake between groups, and CS-US expectancies decreased overall without group differences.
population_specificity: Chocolate-loving female students trying to eat less chocolate in daily life (N = 71).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and performance of the Chocolate percutaneous transluminal angioplasty balloon catheter in patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: The study found that the Chocolate balloon achieved acute procedural success in 85.1% of cases, with low dissection rates (0%) and minimal bailout stenting (1.6%). Long-term outcomes included 78.5% freedom from target lesion revascularization, 97.2% freedom from major amputation, and 93.3% freedom from all-cause mortality at 12 months.
population_specificity: 262 patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (290 femoropopliteal lesions) across 30 US centers.
